huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: This is very remote, very steep, insanely rugged country.  There is little to no cell coverage in most of the bighorn sheep habitat.  As in most bighorn sheep habitat, hunters should be in excellent physical condition prior to the hunt as most hunters end up walking dozens of miles and climbing thousands of feet prior to harvesting their ram.  As with most bighorn sheep habitat, there is an abundance of cliffs.  Be very careful scaling cliffs.  It is advised that you bring extra rope to assist with getting through difficult ledges.   A GPS unit is very handy on this unit to not only mark sheep and routes but also places where you can get through the ledges as they are relatively rare.  Hunters can sometimes spend hours hiking along trying to find a way through the ledges and wasting time and energy.  Bring plenty of water.  It can be warm in November and there is very little water on the unit.  Water in the Green River is plentiful but is tough on most portable water filters as it generally runs pretty muddy.    A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to travel to reach service.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 66.7~1000 (entire Nine Mile unit)~440 (entire Nine Mile unit)~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
u>Location of harvest: The core area where most bighorn reside and are harvested is along the lower Price River and lower Green River in Gray Canyon. Probably 75% of the harvest occurs here. There are small concentrations of sheep near Lila Canyon where people can harvest sheep. Sheep can be found down along the river and canyon bottoms all the way up through the cliffs to the top. It is rare to find sheep on the juniper covered mesas on the top. The confluence of the Price River and Green River tends to have the highest concentrations of sheep. There are no known sheep north of Rabbit Valley along the Green River so I wouldn't spend much time there. Bighorn observations in lower Range Creek are also quite rare. Common spots where sheep are found from south to north include Blue Castle Canyon, Long Canyon, Short Canyon, Sand Knolls Canyon, the lower Price River, and Jenny Canyon. Sheep can also be found on Bighorn Mountain and along the face of the Book Cliffs facing SR-6 as far north as Sunnyside.


Scouting Tips: It is good to do pre-season scouting to learn country. However, it is very hot on this unit during the summer months so plan accordingly. You will need a good pair of binoculars and a spotting scope. This unit looks a lot more like desert bighorn sheep habitat than Rocky Mountain bighorn habitat. It is dry and cliffy. During the summer you will most likely see groups of ewes, lambs, and young rams. Many of the larger harvestable rams will not move in with the ewes and be available for harvest until the rut begins in late October. Do not be alarmed if there are no big rams in the summer. They will show up by November. Hunting generally gets better the later you go. The peak of the rut tends to be the week of Thanksgiving. Find groups of ewes and lambs and often times a new ram will be with the ewe group each day as rams are moving alot in November between ewe groups. If you need to get a feel for how to judge a ram, it is advised that you go to the town of Sunnyside during the summer months. From April to September each year there is occasionally a group of 5 to 10 rams that reside in the east part of town and can be viewed at close range (<50 yards). This is an excellent opportunity to judge sheep ages and trophy quality in a low stress environment. Be advised that these sheep have been sporadic in their attendance in recent years will not be in Sunnyside in November when the hunt is going on.

A way to cover lots of ground is to hike up on top of a canyon and glass the other side while having someone else hike the other side of the canyon and look back across the canyon toward you.

Behavior: The month of November is during the bighorn sheep rut. Rams are moving from group to group looking for ewes. Rams can also be observed butting heads. It is advised to occasionally stop and listen for the sound of butting heads it can be a good tool for locating sheep that are otherwise difficult to see. Sheep are generally active throughout the day in November but activity is highest in morning and evening. Bighorn sheep will not be as tied to water in November as it is generally more available that time of year if it has snowed. Bighorn will generally avoid the flat mesa top areas where there is any sort of tree cover. They tend to be found on the steep open cliffs and are occasionally are feeding on the flat canyon bottoms or benches.

Ram vs Ewe: Both rams and ewes have horns. Ram horns are much larger than ewe horns and will form a curl. Many young rams will have a pronounced curl. The best way to recognize mature trophy class bighorn rams is to look for horn mass particularly out near the tip of the horn. Younger rams that are 3 to 5 years old will have plenty of horn length but the horn tips are very thin. Mature rams 6 years and older tend to have thicker horns out near the tips, and thicker bases. Often times if you are close enough you can count horn rings on rams to get an approximate age.

Rocky Mountain Bighorn Sheep rut: The bighorn rut runs during late October and extends through early December with the peak in late November

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: After harvesting a bighorn sheep, you must bring the horns to a DWR office within 72 hours of leaving your hunting area. Checking in a bighorn sheep will fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement. If you received a bighorn sheep permit and did not hunt or did not harvest, you must complete your harvest survey online or by calling toll-free 1-800-221-0659 within 30 days of the season end date printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you being unable to apply for big game permits in subsequent years.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Over 90% of the bighorn sheep habitat is on public land
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: No WMA's occur on this unit
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: No developed campgrounds on this unit.  Plenty of dispersed camping opportunities exist.  Many camp along the lower Price River road east of Woodside
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The lower Price River Road is accessed from SR-6 at the town of Woodside.  You can truck for a few miles down the river.  You will need an ATV to continue across the river and up on the Beckwith Plateau.  A good spot to look at the eastern part of the unit is to travel up the Hastings Road on the east side of the Green River.  This is accessed in the town of Green River near the east I-70 interchange.  You can travel north up this road and look across the river at the lower portions of Long, Short, Sand Knolls, and Price River Canyons.  The Horse Canyon road is accessed from SR-6 about 25 miles south of Price, it will take you to the abandoned Horse Canyon mine and then to Little Park and eventually Turtle Canyon and Range Creek.  The Lila Canyon road is a paved road that goes to the bottom of the cliffs approximately 30 miles south of Price on SR-6;  there are several dirt roads along SR-6 between Lila Canyon and I70 that will get you closer to base of the cliffs.  From here you can use optics to look for sheep along the cliffs.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV's are probably the preferred vehicle on the very few roads that exist on this unit.  An ATV is necessary to travel on the Lower Price River Road up to the Beckwith Plateau.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Duchesne, and Emery counties--Boundary begins at exit 164 on I-70 near the town of Green River; west on I-70 to US-6; north and west on US-6 to SR-123; east and north on SR-123 through the town of Sunnyside to the Water Canyon/Bruin Point Road; northeast on this road to the summit at Bruin Point and the headwaters of Range Creek; southeast along the Range Creek drainage bottom to the Green River; south along the Green River to Swasey's Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Price. Boundary questions? Call Price office, 435-613-3700.
